Imagine you're about to time block 2 events for tomorrow. One takes 120 minutes, the other 75. You want to know exactly how much time it takes, you take your phone, use the calculator app, and add up 120 + 75.

In binary that’s 01111000 + 01001011.

At the end of today's blog you’ll have a deeper understanding of how computers, and even your phone, think to make bit-by-bit calculations in addition.

If you’re not familiar with binary check out Binary Part-0 where we dive into basic binary.

Binary addition under the hood

We have five components. Three to get to a total amount of bits, and two to implement logic on the total amount of bits.

To get to a total amount of bits we use, inp_a, inp_b, and carry_in. Carry in is an overflow of the previous bit-by-bit calculation.

Sum is used to get a byte as the end result.

Carry out to check if we have overflow.

Sum and carry out use both logic, to get an output.

To receive a byte as output and check if memory can allocate it on the stack or heap, logic gates are used for carry_in and carry_out.

Sum makes 2X use of a more complex logic gate named XOR.

XOR is created by basic gates called; AND, NOT, and OR. Here I show you an XOR gate in a table using basic gates AND, NOT, and OR:

ADD EXAMPLE

Sum then looks look like:

ADD EXAMPLE

Now let’s move to carry out.

Carry out is used to detect overflow, meaning, there’s no storage left to point to.

Carry out is created using logic gates AND, and OR, here I illustrate carry out using both gates:

ADD EXAMPLE

We use logic gates in addition because that’s exactly how our CPU communicates: a CPU contains transistors which are the starting point before each logic gate, when enough voltage is received at the transistor it communicates ON, if no voltage, OFF. Then it goes through the logic gate, depending on the gate the right logic is used.

Let’s look at the full adder below using the five elements: Inp_a, Inp_b, Carry_in, Sum and Carry_out.

Each row represents a bit-by-bit calculation, starting from least significant bit (LSB) on the right hand side (bit_0 in the full adder execution table) to the most significant bit (MSB) left (bit_7 in the full adder execution table).

ADD TABLE



Note: Because computers start counting at index 0 we will do that too, bit_0 therefore represents the first bit in the byte, and bit_7 the last bit. In decimal, the total range would be eight bits.

You can read the remaining byte that would be the return value of a mathematical operation in the Sum column; the return value is created by repeating the bit-by-bit addition process 8 times.

The truth table explained

Carry_in is the overflow of the previous calculation. Once we have a carry_in we know that the previous Carry_out calculation was 1 bit overflow.

If we at the end of the truth table end up with one bit overflow we know the program may not compile for the user, or the CPU adds another byte if memory allows.

The sum tells the CPU what value to store in the byte after completing the full adder calculation which you will read on your phone after doing the calculation as a decimal number.

This is part I of a multi-part series exploring how binary logic powers real computing. I’m sharing what I learn as I go, from carry logic to CPUs and memory.
